reasoning:
The critique targets a specific sub-argument in §3.3: that (on bounded, separate-aggregation views) even a 1/10^22 fraction of ‘bads’ prevents a mostly-great future because the absolute quantity of bads becomes large when multiplied by ~10^22 star-systems. If that scaling argument failed, it would weaken one route to “views are fussy,” but the paper has multiple other independent supports for ‘no easy eutopia’ (fragility/product-of-factors; unbounded/linear arguments; other sources of fussiness), so centrality is moderate.

On strength: it correctly notes that the star-count arithmetic is illustrative and that some implicit assumptions about additivity/separability and moral measure are doing work. However, it somewhat overstates the arbitrariness: if bads aggregate separately and approximately add across space, changing the “unit” (stars vs people vs computational capacity) doesn’t remove the basic point, because total ‘bad mass’ still scales with total resources/population. The proposed alternatives (local saturation, quarantine, worst-pocket dominance) correspond to substantively different normative aggregation rules (non-additive, non-separable, or maximin-ish), which may be “plausible” but aren’t argued for here and would amount to switching away from the class of views §3.3 is analyzing rather than showing an internal flaw in the derivation. So it raises a real modeling/assumption-pressure point but doesn’t by itself overturn the result.

Relevance is fairly high within Forethought’s agenda because it engages the internal technical apparatus for ‘fussiness’ (Tier-2-ish in their framework) and asks for a principled account of how disvalue composes over space—an issue that bears on their value-function taxonomy—but it’s not squarely a Tier 3 live strategic dispute. Overall reflects modest damage (strength×centrality) with some credit for pointing to a potentially important hidden assumption.
title: "Arbitrary Moral Granularity Undermines Resource Catastrophe Claim"
